source.name: Metro Nashville Public Works - Waste Services
source.notes: Based on official Nashville Waste Services Recycle Right guidelines. NO glass in curbside recycling — glass must go to drop-off locations. Bi-weekly collection.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty, clean, and dry
Caps can stay on or be removed
Place loose in recycling bin by 6 AM on collection day with arrow toward street
notes: Nashville accepts plastic beverage bottles curbside
Bi-weekly collection; check your schedule
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still inside
Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Plastic jugs
instructions: Empty, rinse, and dry
Replace cap or leave off
Place loose in recycling bin
notes: Includes milk, juice, laundry, and bath product jugs
commonMistakes: Don't include jugs that held motor oil or chemicals
Don't crush; leave in original shape for sorting

materials.name: Plastic jars and food containers
instructions: Empty, rinse clean, and dry
Place loose in recycling bin
notes: Nashville accepts rigid plastic jars for food items
commonMistakes: Don't include containers with food residue
Don't include plastic takeout containers or cups — those are trash in Nashville

materials.name: Kitchen and bath plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place loose in recycling bin
notes: Kitchen and bathroom plastic bottles are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include tubes (toothpaste, lotion tubes) — those are trash

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place loose in recycling bin
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
No need to crush cans
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food or liquid inside
Don't include aluminum foil pans or trays — Nashville doesn't list those as accepted

materials.name: Steel and tin food cans
instructions: Empty, rinse, and dry
Labels can stay on
Place loose in recycling bin
notes: Food and beverage cans are accepted in Nashville recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue
Don't include aerosol cans unless specifically listed

materials.name: Corrugated cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (tape is OK)
Place in or beside recycling bin
notes: Must be clean, empty, and dry
Nashville requires flattening
commonMistakes: Don't include wet or food-soiled cardboard
Don't include wax-coated cardboard

materials.name: Paper and newspapers
instructions: Place loose in recycling bin
Do not bag in plastic
notes: Clean, dry paper is accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include shredded paper loose — it's too small to sort
Don't include wet or food-soiled paper

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Place loose in recycling bin
Staples and bindings are OK
notes: Glossy paper is accepted in Nashville recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include magazines in plastic bags

materials.name: Mail and envelopes
instructions: Place loose in recycling bin
Window envelopes are OK
notes: Junk mail and regular mail accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include padded/bubble mailers — those are trash

materials.name: Food and beverage cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place loose in recycling bin
notes: Nashville accepts cartons including shelf-stable (Tetra Pak) types
commonMistakes: Don't include cartons with liquid still inside
Don't flatten — leave in shape for sorting

materials.name: Cereal and food boxes
instructions: Remove inner plastic bag/liner and trash it
Flatten the box
Place loose in recycling bin
notes: Paperboard boxes from kitchen/pantry items are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic liner — that's trash
Don't include frozen food boxes — those have wax/plastic coating

materials.name: Tissue boxes
instructions: Remove the plastic film from the opening
Flatten and place in recycling bin
notes: The cardboard box is recyclable; the tissues themselves are trash
commonMistakes: Don't include used tissues — those are trash
Remove the plastic opening film

materials.name: Toilet paper and paper towel rolls
instructions: Place empty cardboard tubes in recycling bin
notes: Nashville specifically lists these as accepted
commonMistakes: Only the cardboard tube is recyclable, not the paper towel itself

materials.name: Glass bottles
instructions: DO NOT put in curbside recycling bin
Take to a Nashville glass drop-off site or Convenience Center
Empty and rinse before drop-off
notes: IMPORTANT: Nashville does NOT accept glass in curbside recycling
Glass must go to designated drop-off locations
This is one of Nashville's most important rules
commonMistakes: Don't put glass in your curbside recycling bin — it contaminates other materials
Don't put broken glass in recycling; wrap and trash

materials.name: Glass jars
instructions: DO NOT put in curbside recycling bin
Take to a Nashville glass drop-off site or Convenience Center
Empty, rinse, and remove metal lids
notes: Nashville does NOT accept glass curbside — all glass goes to drop-off
Metal lids can be recycled separately in curbside bin
commonMistakes: Don't put glass jars in your recycling bin
Don't put broken glass in recycling

materials.name: Plastic bags and wrap
instructions: Place in trash
Or return to grocery store drop-off bins
Never put in recycling bin
notes: Plastic bags jam recycling machinery
Many Nashville grocery stores have bag collection bins
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Don't put any plastic film in curbside recycling

materials.name: Bubble wrap
instructions: Place in trash
Or take to store drop-off with other plastic film
notes: Not accepted in Nashville curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin

materials.name: Plastic wrap and film
instructions: Place in trash
Do not put in recycling bin
notes: All plastic film and wrap is excluded from Nashville curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — it tangles in machinery

materials.name: Styrofoam and polystyrene
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable in Nashville
notes: Styrofoam is explicitly excluded from Nashville recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin
Don't confuse with rigid plastic containers

materials.name: Plastic takeout containers
instructions: Place in trash
Not accepted in Nashville curbside recycling
notes: Nashville specifically excludes plastic takeout containers from recycling
Use the Waste Wizard app if unsure about a specific container
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling even if they have a recycling symbol
The recycling number doesn't mean it's accepted curbside

materials.name: Plastic cups
instructions: Place in trash
Not accepted in Nashville recycling
notes: Nashville excludes plastic cups from curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling even if marked recyclable

materials.name: Plastic tubs (yogurt, butter, etc.)
instructions: Place in trash
Nashville does not accept plastic tubs in curbside recycling
notes: Differs from some other cities that accept tubs
Nashville only accepts plastic bottles, jars, and jugs
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — Nashville only accepts bottles, jars, and jugs

materials.name: Food waste and scraps
instructions: Bag and place in trash
Nashville does not have curbside composting
notes: No municipal composting program; consider home composting
Use the Waste Wizard app for specific items
commonMistakes: Don't put food in recycling bin — it contaminates recyclables
Never pour liquids in recycling bin

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
instructions: Place in trash
Consider home composting
notes: Nashville has no curbside composting program
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in trash
Consider home composting
notes: No curbside composting in Nashville
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Bag securely and place in trash
notes: Not accepted in recycling or any curbside program
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place in trash
Rinse and recycle the container separately if it qualifies
notes: The dairy product itself goes in trash; recycle qualifying containers
commonMistakes: Don't pour milk down the recycling bin
Rinse containers before recycling

materials.name: Bread and baked goods
instructions: Place in trash
Consider home composting for plain bread
notes: No curbside composting in Nashville
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Place in trash
Great for home composting if you have a bin
notes: Nashville has no curbside composting program
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin

materials.name: Egg shells
instructions: Place in trash
Great for home composting
notes: No curbside composting in Nashville
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Nashville collects yard waste separately — check Metro schedule
Do NOT put in recycling bin
Use paper yard waste bags or your green cart if provided
notes: Yard waste is explicitly excluded from recycling
Nashville has seasonal yard waste collection
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin
Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Do NOT put in recycling bin
Donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or textile collection bins
Worn-out textiles: place in trash
notes: Nashville explicitly excludes clothing and linens from recycling
Donation is preferred
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling
Donate usable items

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Do NOT put in recycling bin or trash
Take to a Nashville Convenience Center or e-waste collection event
Best Buy also accepts many electronics
notes: Nashville excludes electronics from curbside recycling
Wipe personal data before disposal
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin — wires and electronics jam machinery
Don't put in trash — they contain hazardous materials

materials.name: Hoses
instructions: Place in trash
Do NOT put in recycling bin
notes: Nashville specifically bans hoses from recycling — they tangle in machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling; it's a 'tangler'

materials.name: Wires, chains, and cords
instructions: Place in trash or take to scrap metal recycler
Do NOT put in curbside recycling bin
notes: Nashville specifically excludes wires and chains from recycling
They wrap around machinery and cause shutdowns
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin
Take large amounts of scrap metal to a metal recycler

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT put in trash or recycling
Take to a Nashville Convenience Center or hazardous waste collection event
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries to prevent fires
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling facilities
commonMistakes: Never put in trash or recycling
Tape terminals before disposal

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to Metro Nashville hazardous waste collection or Convenience Center
Latex paint: can dry out with kitty litter, then trash the solid
Oil-based paint: must go to hazardous waste
notes: Never pour paint down drains
commonMistakes: Don't put liquid paint in trash
Don't pour down drain or storm drain

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to an auto parts store or hazardous waste collection
Most AutoZone and O'Reilly locations accept used oil
notes: Never pour down drains or into storm drains
commonMistakes: Don't pour on the ground or down the drain
Don't put in trash

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: If clean and grease-free: flatten and recycle
If heavily soiled with grease: place in trash
Tear off clean portions and recycle those; trash the greasy parts
notes: Only clean cardboard is recyclable in Nashville
Food contamination ruins recycling batches
commonMistakes: Don't recycle a greasy pizza box — grease contaminates paper recycling

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in trash
Plastic-lined cups are not recyclable in Nashville
notes: The plastic lining makes these non-recyclable despite being paper
Plastic lids are also trash
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the plastic lining can't be separated

materials.name: Coffee pods and K-Cups
instructions: Place in trash
Too small and multi-material to recycle curbside
notes: Some brands offer mail-back recycling programs
Check the Waste Wizard app for specific brands
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — they contain mixed materials (plastic, foil, coffee grounds)

materials.name: Plastic straws and utensils
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable in Nashville
notes: Too small for sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling even if marked recyclable

materials.name: Candy wrappers
instructions: Place in trash
Metallized film is not recyclable
notes: Looks metallic but is actually layered plastic — not aluminum
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the metallic appearance is deceiving

materials.name: Chip bags and snack pouches
instructions: Place in trash
Metallized film is not recyclable
notes: The metallic interior cannot be separated for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up into a fist-sized ball
Place in recycling bin
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with food baked on
Small pieces get lost — ball them together

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Do not puncture or crush
Place in recycling bin
notes: Only empty aerosol cans are accepted
Non-empty aerosol cans are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized or not empty
Don't puncture the can

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition — Nashville Public Library, Goodwill
If damaged, place in recycling bin
notes: Donating is always better than recycling
Remove hardcover book covers if thick/laminated
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in trash
Too small for recycling machinery to sort
notes: Shredded paper falls through screens and contaminates recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in recycling
Some recyclers accept it in a sealed paper bag — not Nashville curbside

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Plain paper wrapping: recycle
Metallic, glittery, or plastic-coated wrapping: trash
Paper gift bags without glitter: recycle
Tissue paper: trash
notes: Do the scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, it's paper and recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle metallic or glitter wrapping paper
Remove tape and bows

materials.name: Greeting cards
instructions: Plain paper cards: recycle
Cards with glitter, metallic, or electronic parts: trash
Remove any plastic or metallic additions
notes: Simple paper greeting cards are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle musical/electronic greeting cards
Don't recycle heavily glittered cards

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to Metro Nashville hazardous waste collection or Convenience Center
Do not puncture, crush, or put in trash
Many propane retailers accept returns
notes: Pressurized containers are dangerous in trash or recycling
commonMistakes: Never put in trash or recycling — explosion risk

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to Home Depot, Lowe's, or hazardous waste event
LED and incandescent: wrap and place in trash
Never put any bulbs in recycling bin
notes: CFL and fluorescent bulbs contain mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin
Don't break CFL bulbs — mercury vapor is harmful

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a pharmacy drug take-back kiosk
Nashville police stations often have drug drop boxes
Do not flush medications
notes: Flushing medications contaminates water supply
commonMistakes: Don't flush down toilet
Don't put in trash without deactivating

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to hazardous waste collection or a restaurant grease recycler
Small amounts: absorb with paper towels and trash
notes: Never pour cooking oil down the drain — it causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drain

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Bag and place in trash
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Receipts
instructions: Place in trash
Thermal paper contains BPA and cannot be recycled
notes: Most receipts are thermal paper, which contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — BPA contaminates the paper stream

materials.name: Paper towels and napkins
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable due to food contamination and fiber breakdown
notes: Consider home composting for unbleached paper towels
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin

materials.name: Paper plates and bowls
instructions: Place in trash
Food contamination makes them non-recyclable
notes: Even unused paper plates often have coatings that prevent recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling even if unused — most have plastic/wax coatings

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Place in trash
Food-soiled paper is not recyclable in Nashville
notes: Grease and food residue make these non-recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Frozen food boxes
instructions: Place in trash
Coated with plastic/wax to resist moisture
notes: Unlike regular paperboard, frozen food boxes have coatings that prevent recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — they look like cereal boxes but have different coatings

materials.name: Paper egg cartons
instructions: Clean paper/pulp egg cartons: recycle
Remove any remaining egg residue
notes: Only paper/pulp cartons; not foam or plastic
commonMistakes: Don't recycle styrofoam egg cartons — those are trash

materials.name: Styrofoam egg cartons
instructions: Place in trash
Styrofoam is not recyclable in Nashville
notes: Foam cartons are not accepted in any Nashville recycling program
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer or Nashville Convenience Center
Most tire shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
notes: Illegal to dump tires
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or recycling
Don't dump on the curb

materials.name: Smartphone and cell phone
instructions: Factory reset and remove personal data
Take to Best Buy, Staples, or a carrier store for recycling
Or take to a Nashville Convenience Center
notes: Contains valuable recoverable materials
Never put in trash due to battery fire risk
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash — lithium batteries are a fire hazard
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Place in a puncture-proof sharps container
Take to a pharmacy or Metro Nashville hazardous waste event
Never put loose in trash or recycling
notes: Loose sharps are a serious safety hazard for waste workers
commonMistakes: Never put loose needles in trash
Never put in recycling

materials.name: Milk carton (refrigerated)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in recycling bin
notes: Both gable-top and aseptic cartons are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include with liquid still inside

materials.name: Large/bulky items
instructions: Schedule a bulky item pickup with Metro Nashville: 615-862-8750
Or take to a Nashville Convenience Center
Donate if in usable condition
notes: Nashville offers scheduled bulky item collection
Some items may have a fee
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling a pickup

materials.name: Window glass, mirrors, and ceramics
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in trash
Not recyclable — different glass composition than bottles
notes: Window glass, mirrors, and ceramics melt at different temperatures than bottle glass
They contaminate glass recycling — do NOT take to glass drop-off sites
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling or glass drop-off
Don't confuse with bottle glass

materials.name: Toothpaste and squeezable tubes
instructions: Place in trash
Multi-material tubes are not recyclable curbside
notes: Made of mixed plastic and aluminum layers that can't be separated
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling even though they feel like plastic

materials.name: Pots, pans, and metal cookware
instructions: Take to a scrap metal recycler or Nashville Convenience Center
Do NOT put in curbside recycling bin
notes: Too large and heavy for curbside sorting machinery
Scrap metal recyclers often pay for metal cookware
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling bin
Don't put in trash if in usable condition — donate

materials.name: Cleaning wipes and disinfecting wipes
instructions: Place in trash
Never flush wipes — even 'flushable' ones
notes: Wipes do not break down and clog sewer systems
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't flush — they cause sewer blockages

materials.name: Dryer sheets and fabric softener sheets
instructions: Place in trash
notes: Coated with chemicals; not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Pesticides and household chemicals
instructions: Take to Metro Nashville hazardous waste collection or Convenience Center
Keep in original labeled container if possible
Never pour down drains or storm drains
notes: Check nashville.gov for hazardous waste event schedules
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or recycling
Don't pour down any drain

materials.name: Small appliances
instructions: Take to a Nashville Convenience Center
Or donate if in working condition — Goodwill, Habitat ReStore
Schedule bulky item pickup for large appliances: 615-862-8750
notes: Do not put in curbside recycling or trash
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin
Don't put in trash — take to Convenience Center

materials.name: Cardboard drink carriers and holders
instructions: If clean and dry: place in recycling bin
If food-soiled: place in trash
notes: Made from paperboard, same as cereal boxes
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if wet or food-contaminated

recycle: Food and beverage cartons (milk, juice, broth)
Toilet paper and paper towel rolls
Plastic bottles, jars, and jugs (beverage, kitchen, laundry, bath)
trash: Plastic bags, wrap, bubble wrap, film
Plastic takeout containers, cups, and tubs
Food waste and food scraps (no curbside composting)
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

recycle: GLASS — Nashville does NOT accept glass curbside; take to drop-off sites
Plastic bags, wrap, and film — they jam machinery
Plastic takeout containers, cups, and tubs

tips: NO GLASS in curbside recycling — take glass bottles and jars to Nashville drop-off sites or Convenience Centers
Place bin out by 6 AM with arrow pointing toward the street
Recycling is collected bi-weekly; check your schedule at nashville.gov
Items must be loose, clean, empty, and dry
Caps can stay on plastic bottles or be removed
No loose caps in the bin
When in doubt, use the Nashville Waste Wizard app
Plastic bags contaminate recycling — never bag recyclables
Only bottles, jars, and jugs for plastic — no tubs, cups, or takeout containers

locations.name: Nashville Glass Recycling Drop-off Sites
locations.address: Multiple locations — check nashville.gov for nearest site
locations.notes: Nashville has multiple glass-only drop-off sites throughout the city. Glass is NOT accepted in curbside recycling.

locations.name: East Nashville Convenience Center
locations.address: 943 Doctor Richard G Adams Dr, Nashville, TN 37207
locations.notes: Full-service drop-off for items not accepted curbside

locations.name: Omohundro Convenience Center
locations.notes: Full-service drop-off for items not accepted curbside

locations.name: Metro Nashville Household Hazardous Waste
locations.notes: Check nashville.gov for collection event dates and Convenience Center drop-off options
